This means that actinides tend to be more stable in higher oxidation states than lanthanides. Additionally, the lanthanides have a lower redox potential than the actinides, which means they are more readily oxidized in reactions.
In terms of the electronic configuration, the actinides have a full f-electron shell, while the lanthanides have a partially filled f-electron shell. This means that the actinides have a higher stability due to the full electron shell, while the lanthanides have a lower stability due to the partially filled shell.
Overall, the lanthanides and actinides have different properties and characteristics due to their different electronic configurations and the way they form bonds.
